awd_titl_txt: FRG: Collaborative Research: Algebra and Geometry Behind Link Homology
awd_abstract_narration:
The Hecke algebra and its generalizations are central objects in modern representation theory. They naturally appear in number theory, representation theory, algebraic geometry, and even low-dimensional topology. A categorification of the Hecke algebra was used to define a new topological invariant of knots and links, known as HOMFLY-PT homology. However, it is extremely difficult to compute this invariant from the definition. The project is focused on understanding the algebraic, geometric, and combinatorial structure of link homology and categorified Hecke algebras, with the goal of unifying, deepening, and clarifying connections between these concepts.

Recent progress strongly indicates a connection between the HOMFLY-PT homology and algebraic geometry of the Hilbert scheme of points on the plane, a central object in modern algebraic geometry and geometric representation theory.  In this collaborative project, the investigators plan to compare and unify different approaches to the study of this connection and to develop the fundamental understanding of the relation between the category of Soergel bimodules and the Hilbert scheme. They also plan to provide an algebro-geometric construction of HOMFLY-PT homology and to understand its relation to the combinatorics of Macdonald polynomials.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
The knot homologies provide computational tools for study and classification of knots in the three-dimensional space. The HOMFLYPT homology yields the most complete set of invariants of a knot. However, the HOMFLYPT homology is notoriously difficult to compute.
One of the goal of the project was to develop new tools for quicker computation of the HOMFLYPT homology. Guided by suggestions from string theory, PI proposed a construction for the HOMFLYPT homology that uses geometry of the compactified configuration space of points on the plane. PI proved that the proposed construction indeed yields the HOMFLYPT homology. PI also found formulas for HOMFLYPT homology for a large class of knots that are related to plane singularities.


The developed geometric theory allowed PI to explain the richness of the HOMFLYPT homology. PI have shown that the most of the other knot homologies can be obtained from the geometric model of HOMLFLYPT homology by a very clear geometric operation.  Roughly, to obtain other homology theories, one has to constrain the points in the above-mentioned configuration space to some very natural subspaces.

The string theoretic origin of the above HOMFLYPT proposal can be traced to a particular class of topological quantum field theory, which is known as topological twist gauged three-dimensional sigma model. PI developed a rigorous mathematical theory that underlies such theories in the case when the target is a vector space. 


As part of the project, PI provided training for graduate students. PI also co-organized four week-long workshops during the years of the support.
